importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the announcement that Colombia has recalled its ambassador to the US, marking a significant escalation in diplomatic tensions between the two nations.
Previous diplomatic recall of Colombia's ambassador to the US in July, indicating a recurring pattern of diplomatic friction between Colombia and the US over drug policy and political allegations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period immediately following the US missile attacks on drug-smuggling vessels, during which tensions escalated, including the recall of the Colombian ambassador and threats of economic sanctions.

keyTakeAways: Colombia has recalled its ambassador to the United States, Daniel García-Peña, for consultations, citing US attacks on alleged drug-smuggling vessels and threats of economic sanctions as key reasons.
This is the second time the Colombian ambassador has been recalled this year, following a similar action in July when the US recalled its ambassador to Bogotá.
US President Donald Trump accused President Gustavo Petro of being an 'illegal drug leader' and threatened to cut large-scale payments and subsidies to Colombia.

The US has deployed warships in the Caribbean and launched missile attacks on seven vessels it claims are involved in drug trafficking, resulting in at least 30 deaths, with Petro accusing the US of 'murder' involving Colombian nationals.
A Colombian citizen aboard the latest vessel attacked was returned alive to Colombia, fueling national outrage and diplomatic strain.
The US plans to raise tariffs on Colombian goods, signaling potential economic retaliation against Colombia.
Colombia's Foreign Minister Rosa Yolanda Villavicencio Mapy confirmed the recall and stated that the government will announce further decisions in due course.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Colombia has recalled its ambassador to the United States, Daniel García-Peña, for consultations, in response to US missile attacks on alleged drug-smuggling vessels in the Caribbean, which have resulted in at least 30 deaths, including some believed to be Colombian nationals. The move follows a previous diplomatic recall in July and comes amid escalating tensions between Colombian President Gustavo Petro and US President Donald Trump, who accused Petro of being a drug leader and threatened to cut financial subsidies and raise tariffs on Colombian goods. Colombia claims that the US actions amount to murder and that the attacks are politically motivated, while the US maintains it is acting to combat drug trafficking. The situation underscores a deepening diplomatic rift between the two nations over drug policy, sovereignty, and national security.
title: Colombian Ambassador to US Recalled for Consultations
